Monsieur Adama est né vers 1973 à Lofigué Cercle de KADIOLO. Père de 4 enfants  il dans une famille nucléaire à Noumousso - Kadiolo (troisième région administrtive de la république du Mali).
Il mène les activités de commercialisation de céréales depuis cinq ans. Son expérience dans ce domaine, lui a valu une bonne réputation et il réçoit  beaucoup de commandes de céréales, notamment du maïs. Ainsi pour avoir les réssources nécessaires afin de satisfaire ses clients, il décida de collaborer avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. Il est à son 7 eme  cycle maintenant, les 6 prêts passés ont été remboursés sans problème.  
Ce prêt lui permettra d’acheter 5 tonnes de maïs et 1 tonne d’arachide. Il s’approvisionne dans les villages avoisinants Kadiolo. Les produits sont stockés dans son magasin. Il  les revend au comptant à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes venant de SIKASSO et de BAMAKO. 
Avec ce prêt, il envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 150 000 FCFA. Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
 Il compte devenir un grossiste de bonne renommé à fin de satisfaire ses nombreux clients qui ne cessent de croître.

loans.use: Pour acheter de céréales

loans.name: Orlandine Agusto

texts.es:
Orlandine con 29 años de edad, de estado civil separado,vive en casa propia de material rústico, junto a su hijo, ene l distrito de Cañaris,provincia de Ferreñafe,departamento de Lambayeque,país Perú.El cuanta con muy buenas referencias tanto personales como laborales por parte de los moradores de la zona. Los habitantes de esta localidad se dedican en su mayoría a la agricultura,comercio y ganadería.

El se dedica a la agricultura, específicamente al cultivo de café, con una experiencia en el rubro de 10 años. El préstamo que se le otorgará lo utilizará en labores agricolas, aplicaciones e incorporaciones de productos fito sanitarios, fertilizantes, y mano de obra para su cosecha. De esta manera lo ayudará a la mejora tanto fisiológica, morfológica y productiva de su cultivo, así como también tener una cosecha oportuna, y por ende tendrá mayor producción, una mejor calidad de producto, por lo cual no tendrá problemas en vender su producto.

Orlandine es socio nuevo para Edpyme Alternativa.Firma con aval.

loans.use: lo utilizará en labores agricolas, aplicaciones e incorporaciones de productos fito sanitarios, fertilizantes, y mano de obra para su cosecha.

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en: Nancy is married with three children. She is a member of Mercury Women Group which helps women in mobilization of savings and provides small credit to members. From her savings, she has been able to buy a dairy cow and still continues to save with the group. She sells and grows maize, beans, and vegetables; also, she has a dairy cow which gives her milk for sale and home consumption.  In addition, she has two rental rooms in Gatangara-Kangema. She gets $28 from the two rooms and $42 from sell of milk per month. She is working very hard to reach a turn over of at least $100 per month. With this she will have the capacity to save small amounts to help her in supporting her family.

loans.use: She wants to buy hybrid seeds and animal feeds to increase productivity.

loans.name: Patrick Sifuna

texts.en: Patrick is married with seven children. His wife is a small-scale farmer. Patrick finished his secondary school and then went to a training institute. After starting his business four years ago, he is able to support his family through his business. With a loan of US$100 from PEMCI, he will be able to boost his stock in order to improve his income and broaden his capital base in the business. His business is now sufficient enough to accommodate customer’s needs.

loans.use: Sifuna's Timber Yard

loans.name: Angela

texts.en:
Angela has three children and one adopted child. On her farm she plants rice and relies on this production to feed her family. She lives at home with one of her grandchildren, her daughter and, the adopted son. With the loan she will buy fertilizer and seeds for rice production. Angela suffers from kidney disease and must go through dialysis once a week for treatment. She hopes that she will be able to contract someone to help work her land so she can pay her medical expenses without bothering her children.

Communal Banking in Baba

This borrower is part of the newest and largest Communal Bank in the recently developed Mifex Rural Finance Program. All of the members of the Centro Agricola de Baba Communal Bank are part of an Association of Rice Farmers in the county of Baba in rural Ecuador. Their association works cooperatively to cultivate rice and commercialize the product after it has grown. As an association, Centro Agricola helps the farmers by providing access to machinery and training services. The farmers from Centro Agricola have received special instruction on financial responsibility and accounting from Codemicro, an organization that specializes in training programs geared towards the rural sector.

The members of Centro Agricola de Baba will use the micro-loans to prepare their lands and cultivate rice on their farms. Because they form part of a communal bank, they are all each others' guarantors for the loan. This means that if for some reason one person in the group cannot fully repay the loan, the other borrowers and the Centro Agricola de Baba Association are responsible for the amount in default. The members of the bank also participate in a program designed to teach and encourage savings among the group. Promoting savings is often forgotten in many micro-finance programs, but Mifex believes that is imperative for the communities we works with to have capital reserved for future investments or unexpected difficulties.

Below is more information about Baba compiled by Luis Crespo and Robert Edgar of the Mifex team when evaluating the potential of the sector for the Rural Finance Program.

Economy of Baba

The people of Baba have been organized since the days of Gran Colombia when Ecuador was yet to be a country. The area has always been popular because of the extremely productive lands that gave way to cultivation of cacao for decades. Now Baba is a county in the province of Los Rios in the coastal region of Ecuador. For most of the latter part of the 20th Century it was a cacao and banana producing sector. Most of the surrounding areas of Baba in Los Rios are owned by big large companies such as Dole, but Baba is a sector characterized the small and informal farms.

Rice production has now turned into the main economic activity of the area as about 80% of the people are rice farmers. Cacao is still very popular in the area, but because of the long cultivation cycle people prefer to invest in rice. The lands in Baba are very fertile though, and most farmers in the sector often grow other crops, such as plantains and soy beans, as secondary sources of income. Many farmers also keep livestock as emergency sources of food and income, commonly resorting to selling a chicken or pig if they are in need of cash.

Rice Farming

Most of the people in the Baba area are small farmers. They produce about 80 sacks of rice per hectare of land. In order to farm they first must prepare the lands by removing weeds, plowing and leveling the lands. This is the most difficult part for the farmers in Baba, who often lack the necessary machinery to properly plough the lands for rice production. After appropriately preparing the lands, the farmers fill an area with water to form what is known as a paddy field, because rice is a very water intensive crop. The rice seeds are either dispersed freely (the process is known as boleo in Spanish) or hand sowed. Once the rice has grown, most farmers rent machinery that helps them gather their production.

Access to Credit

One of the biggest struggles in the area has been the lack of credit due to the absence of any type of financial institution. Because people do not count on formal financial finance, they have turned to loan sharks for financing. They have been affected by expensive lines of credit that exceed 100% interest a year and can be as expensive as 240%. Intermediaries also exploit the farmers because of their outstanding debt. Farmers also lack skills and knowledge to commercialize their products and pay fair prices for their crops.

Risks

The largest risk in the sector is due to absence of watering systems. Although Baba is in the province “Los Rios” (the rivers) there is severe problem with access to water. The lack of infrastructure in the sector does not allow the small farmers to benefit from the presence of the many rivers in the area. If the winter season is too dry, it is likely that the lands will not be sufficiently fertile for rice production in the summer. On the other hand, if there is too much rain there are no drainage systems to prevent flooding and the crops are often ruined. Generally speaking though, Baba is a very productive sector where the lands yield all types of products including rice, cacao, corn, watermelons, plantains, and soy beans.

Loan Use

The loans in this sector will be used to to buy soil, seeds, fertilizer and insecticides. Many of the loans will also go towards renting machinery and equipment necessary to effectively work and prepare the fields. The loan repayment schedule is different from the typical micro-entrepreneur because farmers see the profits from their investments 5 or 6 months after making their initial expenditures. Mifex asks our rural clients only to pay 50% of the capital in the first 6 months of the loan. The rest of the debt must be paid in the seventh and final month.

loans.use: Fertilizer and seeds for rice farming

loans.name: Abdulai

texts.en:
55 year old Abdulai is married with three children. He runs a small shop in the open air market in the Makeni town of Sierra Leone. With his previous loan from Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT), Abdulai was able to increase his business.

He plans to use the funds from his new loan to purchase materials in bulk and sell them wholsale to retailers in more remote Sierra Leonean villages.

loans.use: To add to his inventory of second-hand clothes for wholesale operation.

loans.name: Ximena

texts.es:
Ximena L. Zambrana, married and mother of 7 children, has been a member of Pro Mujer for two years, and is treasurer for the Asociación Cielo Azul (Blue Sky Association) of Villa Adela.

Ximena works buying and selling mobile telecommunication equipment, especially selling cellular telephones. She is not a wholesaler, rather she is an occasional seller who benefits from some contacts in offices and businesses to be able to sell her merchandise. In some cases it is her husband, who works in student transport, who sells equipment to students in the upper years of private high schools in the Southern part of the city of La Paz.

At present, Ximena has an urgent need for capital, in order to be able to increase her stock of merchandise. One of her daughters is having health problems, and needs an operation to remove a tumor. She needs as soon as possible to put together through sales of her products the necessary amount to cover the cost of this intervention.

(Translated from the Spanish by Naomi Johnson, Kiva volunteer)

Ximena L. Zambrana, casada y madre de 7 hijos, pertenece a Pro Mujer hace dos años, y tesorera de la Asociación Cielo Azul de Villa Adela.

Ximena se dedica a la compra y venta de equipos móviles de telecomunicación, principalmente a la venta de teléfonos celulares, ella no es mayorista, sino es vendedora ocasional, aprovecha algunos contactos en oficinas o negocios para poder vender su mercadería, en algunos casos es el esposo, quien trabaja en transporte escolar que logra la venta de algunos equipos a estudiantes de últimos cursos de colegiuos privados de la zona sur de la ciudad de La Paz.

En la actualidad, Ximena precisa con urgencia de capital, para poder incrementar en algo su mercadería, puesto que por cuestiones de salud una de sus hijas debe ser sometida a una operación para la extracción de un tumor, por tanto necesita lo antes posible llegar a reunir mediante la venta de sus productos el monto necesario que cubrirá los gastos de la intervención.

loans.use: Ximena has an urgent need for capital, in order to be able to increase her stock of merchandise. One of her daughters needs an operation to remove a tumor.

loans.name: Diabagate

texts.en:
Diabagaté M. is a dynamic 31 year old woman. M. lives with her family in Treichville, a populated suburb in the south of Abidjan. She sells various crafted hand made pans and utensils in the Treichville Market. She has been selling her goods in the market for many years. M. orders and purchases the products in bulk from craftsmen in a neighboring city. These products resell well in the Abidjan region.

She joined AE&I's microcredit program in July 2004 when she was recommended by her mother, who was already in the program. M. has benefited from different loans and has performed very well so far. She will use this loan to purchase batches of pans from a blacksmith in Ayama (45 miles north of Abidjan).

loans.use: Diabagaté Mariam will use the loan to purchase batches of pans from a blacksmith

loans.name: Nodira

texts.en: U. Nodira is 36 years old, married and has 2 children. Her husband is unemployed, but he has his own microbus and transports people. Nodira has been dealing in children's clothes and boots for about 7 years. It is the single source of income for their family. In 2004, she became a client of Microinvest and she says that  it helped her to expand her business and receive a stable profit. By developing her business she was able to buy one milk cow and her daughter sells milk in their village. This summer, Nodira started to reconstruct her house. (The roof was very damaged by rains and snows, and the walls of the home were damaged.) She planned to finished the repairs by winter, but  she could not because lack of money. The weather is becoming cold now and she wishes that Kiva will help her with extra capital in the amount of $1175.

loans.use: For home reconstruction.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase equipment for her business

loans.name: Elshad

texts.en: Elshad lives in Sumgayit city, he is married and has three children. He runs a sewing workshop. Elshad established this business four years ago, and he now has two more employees. He receives orders from customers, and makes different kinds of clothing. Sometimes he is short of raw materials to fill the orders on time. He heard about Normicro loans and decided to apply for a loan. He wants to borrow $500 for 6 months to buy raw materials such as fabric, thread, needles, etc.

loans.use: To buy raw materials

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace B. is married and has five children. Her husband is a teacher.

Grace runs a local road-side restaurant which specializes in “Banku”, a traditional Ghanaian dish made by soaking maize for three days in water then mixing it into dough which is then served with stew. She is requesting $525 to buy additional products to stock her restaurant.

Grace is also a member of a lending group called “Wisdom Group”, which consists of 14 members in Cape Coast, Ghana.

loans.use: To buy additional products to stock her restaurant.

loans.name: Cristina Yamileth

texts.es:
Mrs. Cristina Garcia is 39 years old married with three kids. Her husband is a construction worker. Ten years ago she started her business selling tortillas, frijoles, cheese, and cream. She starts cooking and selling her tortillas at 5 am and she finishes her day by 7pm. Her humble family looks forward to the future and to achieve their goal of buying a mill. She’s requesting a credit to buy corn and beans.

Translated from Spanish by Mayra Villegas, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Cristina G., de 39 años de edad vive en Laureles Norte con su esposo quien es Albañil y juntos cuidan a sus 3 hijos, doña Cristina es una madre preocupada y atenta a las necesidades de su hijos, desde hace 10 años tiene un negocio de venta de tortilla, frijoles cocidos , queso, cuajada y crema. Desde las cinco de la mañana hasta las siete de la noche pasa echando tortilla para vender y mandar a ventas de comidas que le encargan, sus clientes la comen recién hechas, Viven con humildad pero con mucha ilusión de salir adelante, su sueño es comprar un molino. Solicita un crédito para comprar quintal de maíz y frijoles lo que le resultaría más económico.

loans.use: To buy corn and beans

loans.name: Elvira's Group

texts.es:
The committee consists of 15 hard working women of the barrio Seminario of the city of Caacupé. The group is currently in the 7th cycle of the Mujeres Emprendedoras (enterprising women) program. The majority of the women are in the retail business, such as small grocery stores, kiosks, sale of cold drinks, sale of new and used clothing, etc.

The aforementioned women manage a line of credit in the amount of gs. 1.000.000 for each member through the committee Mujeres Emprendedoras de la Fundación Paraguaya.

The committee was created thanks to Blanca V., who heard that in her neighborhood a group of women were forming a committee. She then visited the Fundación Paraguaya's office to learn about the program and was able to quickly gather 15 women from her neighborhood. In this manner the committee was formed with the minimum number of members required to start the training. Currently this group is one of the most solid ones in terms of working as a team, solidarity and responsibility.

They have held numerous charitable events with the objective of handling the unexpected necessities of its members. Elvira V. is the president of the committee and along with all the other members, is very happy to be part of a program that seeks the development of people with limited resources. Not only did they receive the loan but they also learned that together the can accomplish important objectives that benefit the community as well as the committee's members.

Translated from Spanish by Libertad Leal, Kiva volunteer.

El comité está integrado por 15 señoras trabajadoras del barrio Seminario de la ciudad de Caacupé, el grupo esta actualmente en el 7to. Ciclo del programa Mujeres Emprededoras, la gran mayoría de las señoras se dedican al comercio, como ser despensa, kiosko, venta de bebidas heladas, ropas nuevas y usadas.

Dichas señoras están manejando una línea de crédito promedio de gs. 1.000.000 por cada integrante a través del programa de comité de Mujeres Empredoras de la Fundación Paraguaya.

El comité fue creado gracias a que la señora Blanca V. se entero que en su barrio se estaba formando un comité de mujeres, su curiosidad la llevo a visitar la oficina de la Fundación Paraguaya, a fín de interiorizarse del tema, rápidamente logró reunir a 15 señoras vecinas y así se conformó el comités con la cantidad de integrantes mínima requerida para el inicio de las primeras charlas de capacitación, actualmente este comité es uno de los más solidos en cuanto a trabajo en equipo, solidaridad y responsabilidad.

Ya realizaron numerosas actividades benéficas con el objetivo de cubrir las necesidades imprevistas de sus integrantes., Elvira V. es la presidenta del comité y manisfestó estar muy contenta como todas las integrantes de ser parte de un programa que busca el desarrollo de las personas de escasos recursos, ya que no solamente reciben el préstamo, sino también aprendieron a que unidas pueden lograr objetivos importantes que beneficien a la comunidad, y mismo a las integrantes del comités.

loans.use: To Purchase products such as sugar, herbs, milk, cookies, starch, beef, sodas, beer, a variety of drinks, as well as clothing for men, women and children.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary A. is thirty-five years old. She is married and has three children who are all currently in school. Mary works very hard and with passion to be able to provide better opportunities for her children and send the eldest of them to a medical school. Mary earns income running her own grocery store in one of the busy local markets. She sells items like rice, sugar, vegetable oil, bottled water, canned foods, peanuts, evaporated milk, etc. Currently, Mary is asking for a loan, which she will use to buy more rice, sugar, evaporated milk, vegetable oil, and other goods to increase the stock in her store. Mary belongs to the community group called Nyame Kye (God’s Gift) Trust Group, whose members provide a guarantee for one another as social collateral to help access and repay loans.

loans.use: Purchase of rice and sugar, evaporated milk, vegetable oil, etc.

loans.name: Georgette

texts.fr:
Born around 1962 in Porto Novo, Benin’s political capital, Mrs. Georgette H. B. is married and the mother of five children, three of whom are in her care and at school. She has been living for more than 12 years in Sodjatime, a suburb of Cotonou, where she runs a business selling fresh eggs. The main characteristic of her business is wholesale distribution, a mixture of wholesale and retail, and sometimes just retail. Her minimum daily income is CFA 20,000. She is on her third loan, for which she is requesting CFA 100,000 in order to meet demand.

Translated from French by Sarah Llewellyn, Kiva Volunteer.

Née vers les années 1962 à PORTO NOVO dans la capitale politique du BENIN, dame H. B. Georgette est mariée et mère de 5 enfants dont 3 sont à sa charge et tous scolarisés. Elle réside depuis une dizaine d’années à SODJATIME l’une des banlieues de COTONOU où elle exerce son activité de vente d'œufs frais. La particularité de son activité est la distribution en gros, semi gros et parfois en détails. Elle réalise un chiffre d’affaire minimum journalier de 20 000 francs cfa. Elle est à son troisième crédit pour lequel elle sollicite 100 000F CFA pour faire face à ses demandes.

loans.use: To buy 50 trays of fresh eggs

loans.name: Thoun

texts.en:
Mrs. Thoun T., 45, is a rice farmer who lives in Toul Krous Village, Pursat Province. Her husband, Mr. Chab Khoeurn, sells rocks and earns $3 per day. They have seven children, four of whom are married and live away from the family. The other three are young and help to earn income by working with their father. Mrs. Thoun T. wants to purchase a plowing machine to use for her rice faming but she does not have enough money. She requests a loan of $400 to add to her cash so she can purchase a plowing machine.

About Hattha Kaksekar Limited (HKL): HKL is one of Cambodia's largest and most successful microfinance institutions (MFIs). It is committed to helping its clients achieve their business goals by providing sound financial services, and thereby hopes to contribute to the social and economic development of Cambodia. HKL specifically targets women and poor families in order to help them achieve increased financial security and quality of life, by offering various credit programs and encouraging savings. In accordance with its mission and its commitment to operational and financial sustainability, HKL contributes part of its net profits every year to support social development in education and healthcare.

loans.use: To purchase a plowing machine

loans.name: Juana

texts.es:
Juana is 86 years old and was never able to go to school. She has 7 children and is a native of the community of Calasaya in the district of Juli. She lives in the center of Mazocruz. A member of the communal bank of Julia Jimenez in Mazocruz, with her first loan Juana was able to buy alpaca meat to sell. She's been working for about 7 years now with the communal bank.

With the new loan, which she will repay in 4 payments, she would like to buy more meat for the business. She works together with her husband, who takes care of preparing the meat to sell. They have been working together for 20 years. She hopes that her children will continue with this business.

Juana tiene 86 años de edad sin estudios, casada, madre de siete hijos, ella es natural de la Comunidad de Calasaya, Distrito de Juli, vive en el Jr. Santa Cruz Nº 185 – Centro Poblado de Mazocruz. Integrante del Banco Comunal Julia Jiménez – Mazocruz, con su primer préstamo compró 02 cabezas de alpaca para su posterior venta en carne, viene trabajando aproximadamente siete años con el Banco Comunal. Con este préstamo de S/. 1,000.00 Nuevos Soles, que pagará en 04 cuotas, tiene planificado comprar 08 cabezas de alpaca cada uno cuesta a S/. 120.00 Nuevos Soles, así va incrementando su capital, trabaja conjuntamente con su esposo quien se encarga de carnear de los animales, entrega todos los miércoles y viernes de cada semana a los intermediarios de la Ciudad de Tacna, semanalmente entrega un promedio de 20 a 30 degollados, viene trabajando hace 20 años con este negocio. Su mayor sueño es que sus hijos sigan trabajando con el negocio que ella les enseñó (venta de carne).

loans.use: TO PURCHASE MORE MEAT FOR THEIR BUTCHER SHOP BUSINESS, GROW THEIR INCOME AND CONTINUE TO SUPPORT THEMSELVES.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy garments wholesale and move her small business forward.

loans.name: Santos

texts.es:
La señora Santos tiene 57 años de edad, vive en Manuel Cox 112 del Pueblo Joven Aurora Diaz del distrito de Salaverry, provincia de Trujillo, departamento de La libertad, Perú y pertenece al Banco Comunal Las Auroras en Acción.
Santos estudió hasta el segundo año de primaria lo que ahora equivale a tercer grado, porque su madre era de escasos recursos económicos, no tenia papá y tuvo que trabajar desde muy niña.
Se casó y  hace 7 años quedó viuda, tiene 5 hijos de los cuales 4 ya trabajan y solamente un hijo depende de ella, el cual es estudiante.
Cuenta que empezó su negocio vendiendo comida, luego vendió gas y ahora vende también cerveza. Agradece al movimiento Manuela Ramos porque gracias a él se pudo capitalizar fácilmente.
Su negocio también lo realiza en su casa, ahora cuenta con una socia.
Su primer crédito fue de 300 soles, el cual devolvió en 4 cuotas, con el que incrementó su negocio y compró gas para volverlo a vender.
Con este crédito de 1,000 soles, el cual será cancelado en 6 cuotas, piensa invertir en cerveza.
Santos sueña con ver profesional a su último hijo, ya que a los otros no pudo darles profesión por razones económicas.
texts.en:
Mrs. Santos is 57 years old and lives at 112 Manuel Cox in Aurora Diaz, in the district of Salaverry in the province of Trujillo in the suburb of La Libertad, Perú. She belongs to the Auroras in action community bank. Santos studied until the second year of elementary school, which equates to third grade, because her mother was poor, she did not have a father and had to work since she was very young. She married, but 7 years ago was widowed. She has 5 children, 4 work and only 1 depends on her now because he is still a student. She began her business by selling food. She later sold gas and now also sells beer. She is thankful for the Manuel Ramos movement because thanks to it she could obtain loans easily. Santos operates her business out of her house, and now counts on a partner. Her first loan was 300 soles and she returned itin 4 months. With this loan she expanded her business and purchased gas which she later sold. With the current loan of 1,000 soles, which she will repay in 6 months, she plans on investing in beer. Santos dreams of watching her youngest son become a professional, as her other children could not become professionals for economic reasons.

Translated from Spanish by Jordan Shanker, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase beer to sell

loans.name: Khmao

texts.en: Mrs. Khmao N. is a 28-year-old villager who lives with her husband and her three young children in Damnak Rovang village in Takeo Province, Cambodia. She is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice for sale. Her husband, Mr. Chea San, is a construction worker who earns a small salary. Even though they have different businesses, they do not have enough money to support their family. Therefore, Mrs. Khmao N. decided to ask for a loan to buy a cow for breeding to start new business. She hopes to increase her income and improve her living conditions as a result pf this loan.

loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase piglets, palm oil and operate a restaurant

loans.name: Alice

texts.en: Alice A. L. P., 25, is married and has two children.  She has many years of experience in the grocery shop business. She sells to the villagers and general public seven days per week. She has had one previous loan with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 220 Tala ($91 US).  SPBD loans are Alice’s only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.The loan will be used to purchase goods for her shop because of the holidays and she has to order as many goods as she can in order to make money. Her husband is helping her run the business.

loans.use: Purchase Flour, sugar, tinned fish, twisties, chicken, milk, tomato sauce

loans.name: Yun

texts.en:
Mrs. Yun C., 69, is a widow with three daughters. One of her children is married and lives outside the family home, and one daughter is a hairdresser. Besides her children she also has one son in-law and three grandchildren who are living with her. The family lives in a small village off of the National Road about twenty kilometers south of Phnom Penh.

Yun has been selling grocery items for two years. She buys them from TaKhmao market for resale in her village. Yun is requesting a loan of $1000 to purchase grocery items for resale.

loans.use: To purchase grocery items for resale.

loans.name: Papaloa

texts.en:
Papaloa P., 56, is married with 9 children. She has 4 years of experience in the plantation business. She sells to the general public/villagers 4 days per week. She has 5 previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 750 Tala (~312 USD).

SPBD loans are Papaloa’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Papaloa wants to improve her business in order for it to sustain her and help her family financially.

loans.use: buy chemicals, knives, plant-sprayer, barbed wire, gromozones, and a spade

loans.name: Estela

texts.es:
La señora Estela C. D. M. pertenece al banco comunal “Mujeres Unidas” D. la Comunidad D. Carancas, distrito D. Desaguadero, Provincia D. Chucuito, Departamento D. Puno; D. 51 años D. edad, tiene 6 hijos y no cuenta con estudios. 
Trabaja con el movimiento Manuela Ramos hace 07 años y se inició con un préstamo D. S/. 300.00 nuevos soles monto que invirtió en su negocio D. compra y venta D. coca en las ferias D. Desaguadero.
Actualmente ella requiere el préstamo D. S/. 2800 nuevos soles como capital adicional, para poder incrementar la oferta D. coca en los mercados regionales D. Puno y Arequipa, donD. se percibe una mayor demanda, según refiere; por otro lado pretenD. adquirir ganado para engorD., dada la alta demanda D. carne en la actualidad, con ello brindará una mejor ayuda económica a sus menores hijos.
texts.en:
Mrs. Estela C. D. M. belongs to the Communal Bank “Mujeres Unidas” (United Women) of Carancas, Desaguadero district, Chucuito province, Puno department. She is 51 years old, has 6 children, and no formal schooling. She has worked with Manuela Ramos for 7 years and began with a loan for S/. 300.00 nuevos soles which she invested in buying and selling coca leaf in the Desaguadero markets. Today she needs a loan for S/. 2800 nuevos soles as additional capital in order to be able to increase her coca leaf sales in the regional markets of Puno and Arequipa, which she experiences the highest demand. On the other hand she would also like to acquire cattle to raise, given the high demand today for meat, as it will be able to proviD. greater economic assistance to her young children.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Selling coca leaf and buying cattle to raise and sell as meat

loans.name: Maame Afua

texts.en:
Maame Afua A. started her fish business twenty years ago in Elmina in the central region of Ghana. She prepares and serves her customers very tasty and good quality fish, so many customers buy from her stand. She buys fish from the fishermen and smokes them. She has a strong customer base and her customers travel from the other parts of the region to buy her fish.

She is now 37 years old, married, and the mother of five children. Her husband is an auto mechanic. Currently, two of her children are in school.

She wants to use the loan to buy a larger assortment of fresh fish to increase her sales and income, to support her children's education, and to improve her business's growth. She belongs to the Amazing Grace village bank. She hopes to receive GH¢700 to improve her business by restocking her inventory.

loans.use: To buy more smoked and dried fish

loans.name: Lucky

texts.en: Lucky is 32 years old and married. She has two children. She makes a living by selling women's accessories, specifically bags and belts. Lucky has requested a loan amount of N100,000 to purchase more bags and belts to sell. She sends her thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more bags and belts to sell.

loans.name: Rosita

texts.en:
Rosita A., 50 years old and the mother of 11 children, owns a small rice field, her only source of income to feed and clothe the family. In order to sustain her business, Rosita is requesting a loan of Php 6,000 from CEVI to buy fertilizer, seeds and herbicides. The loan will ensure a good harvest and help her family grow the business.

“I am grateful to CEVI for giving me an opportunity to have a business," she says. “Now I receive not just loans but training and insurance coverage as well,” she added.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer, seeds and herbicides.

loans.name: Lukmanjon

texts.en:
Lukmanjon T. is a 52-year-old married father of 3 children. For 15 years he has been in the business of farming and beekeeping. He started his business when he had difficulty finding employment.  The whole family helps out which has been the key to success for the growth of his business.  He has a steady customer base due to the quality of his products. Lukmanjon is now requesting a loan of 7000 Somoni so he can expand his business and offer better services.  Lukmanjon and his family sincerely thank you for your support.  

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes being a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To expand his farming and beekeeping business.

loans.name: Sun

texts.en:
The woman in the photo is Mrs. Sun B., age 44, who lives in the Province of Pursat in Cambodia, where she earns a living raising pigs. Since 1999, she has run this business and it has provided her with income to attain her standard of living.

She is married with two children who are secondary students: the first child attends class 10 and the other attends class 8. Her husband helps her in raising pigs.

In order to earn extra income, Sun B. will be using the loan to buy more pig-feed and piglets to raise.

loans.use: To buy more pig-feed and piglets to raise

loans.name: Ruth Dinorah

texts.es: Ruth Dinorah E. D. R. resiD. en el municipio D. San Juan Opico del departamento D. La Libertad. Dinorah tiene 49 años D. edad vive con sus cuatro hijos quienes siguen estudiando en la escuela, Dinorah no recibe ayuda económica D. nadie, ha logrado salir adelante con su negocio que es una venta D. antojitos como ella la llama donD. venD. todo tipo D. platillos y boquitas típicas D. El Salvador, El sueño D. Dinorah es seguir creciendo en su negocio exportando antojitos hacia Estados Unidos y es por ello que solicita este crédito ya que necesita comprar suficiente materia prima para sus productos típicos que se venderán en Estados Unidos.
texts.en:
Ruth Dinorah E. D. R. lives in the San Juan Opico municipality in the La Libertad department. Dinorah, 49, lives with her four children who go to school. Dinorah does not receive economic help from anybody. She has been able to get ahead in her business of selling what she calls snacks. She sells dishes and appetizers that are typical in El Salvador. Dinorah’s dream is to continue growing in her business and exporting appetizers to the United States. That is why she is asking for this loan. She needs to buy sufficient raw materials for her typical products, which will be sold in the United States.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy raw materials

loans.name: Lenielyn

texts.en: Lenielyn B. is from the village of Zone 1, Baikingon, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 28 years old, married, and has an infant child. Lenielyn owns and operates a business making and selling food, selling processed food products like longganisa (Filipino-style sausages) in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Lenielyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make longganisa for sale. Lenielyn is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital. This loan will be her 2nd from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of her family. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and to use as working capital

location.town: Zone 1, Baikingon, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Orienta

loans.name: Magna Marlene

texts.es: Magna Marlene C. R. vive en Lourdes, municipio en el departamento de La Libertad. Magna maneja una pupusería en la casa donde vive  con su esposo y sus dos hijas, Fátima de 7 años y Katerine, recién nacida y de apenas un año de edad. El nacimiento de su nueva hija, ha llenado de ilusión a Magna, quien está decidida a trabajar fuerte y con disciplina para sacar su familia adelante. Magna solicita un préstamo para reinvertir en su negocio comprando materia prima para sus pupusas y hacerlo crecer cada vez mas.
texts.en:
Magna Marlene C. R. lives in Lourdes, a town in the "departamento" of La Libertad. Magna operates a "pupeseria" [a shop where she sells "pupesas", a traditional flat bread made from maize] in the house where she lives with her husband and their two daughters, Fatima, 7, and Katerina, a one-year old baby. The birth of her new daughter has fired Magna's hopes for the future and she's decided to work hard to push her family ahead. She is applying for a loan to buy basic supplies for making pupesas and to grow her business.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy supplies for food business

loans.name: Francisca

texts.en:
Being a widow did not hinder Francisca to become successful in life. She is a business minded woman at her retiring age. She started her tailoring shop business since year 2003. She has four children who are already finished with their studies and she is very thankful that all of them now have their own jobs and businesses. She is living peacefully in the village of Calamagui 1st Ilagan, Isabela with her own expense. She enjoys her tailoring business and gives her satisfaction in life. 

Currently, Francisca has expanded a dress shop business in their village. Due to lack of capital, she is now requesting to avail a loan of to PHP8, 000. Aside from tailoring, Francisca also ventured into direct selling of FERN – C (vitamin C) in their village.  She hopes that her loan will make her become more progressive.

loans.use: Business capital

loans.name: God Is Able Group

texts.en:
God is Able is a group of 5 borrowers led by Martin J. who live in Kolahu, Lofa County, Liberia. Martin is 23 years old and married. He has a 2-year-old child and he also cares for a child who was orphaned in the war. Martin was able to attend school, but dropped out in the 9th grade when the war came to Lofa County. He lives in the remote city of Kolahu in rural Lofa County, the breadbasket of Liberia. 

Martin’s sells dry goods, including dry biscuits, palm oil, and clothes that he buys wholesale from nearby Guinea and sells in a temporary market stall in the Kolahu Central Market, Turlay Quarter. He has run his business for 3 years and is successful because of the way he treats his customers. He’s taking the loan to increase his inventory to meet increased demand. His dream is to expand her business so that, one day, he can have the biggest table in the central market. With the profits from his business, Martin dreams of building his own house and sending his child to school.

loans.use: Purchase biscuits, palm oil, and clothes

loans.name: Lauro

texts.es:
El señor Lauro P. tiene ya mas de tres años con su negocio de venta de comida preparada. 
Su negocio está ubicado en la carretera salida a Nuevo Laredo. Este es el ingreso que tiene para su familia ya que tiene tres hijos y les quiere dar lo mejor.
Al negocio le esta haciendo falta un congelador más grande, le está ofreciendo uno a muy buen precio pero no cuenta con el dinero para poder adquirirlo, es por eso que solicita el préstamo y así poder comprar el congelador que le están ofreciendo.
Planea pagar el crédito con las ganancias del negocio.
texts.en:
Lauro P. has operated his own business, selling prepared foods, for more than three years. His business is located at the highway exit for Nuevo Laredo. This activity provides the income for his family; he has three children and he wants to provide the best he can for them. The business he is operating needs a larger freezer, and he has been offered one for a very good price. However, he does not have the money to buy it. For this reason, he is asking for a loan in order to purchase the freezer that is being offered to him. He plans to repay the loan with the profits from his business.

Translated from Spanish by Patricia Linderman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing a freezer

loans.name: 02.05.1.9 Nam Ngạn Group

texts.en:
"Loan N. Thị (51) is a 35 year-old female living in the town of Thanh Hoa.  Loan is the group leader of a 6-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is 9 Nam Ngan (08.1.9 Nam Ngan).


Loan is married and has 2 school-aged children.  To making a living, Loan owns & operates a business venture in the food sector running a food stall.  While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling rice products in the local community.  Loan has been engaged in this business for over 5 years and earns approximately 1500000 VND a month from these activities.


In 2009, Loan joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Loan is requesting for the first time a loan from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.    She is now requesting a new loan of 3000000 VND which will be used to purchase additional products to sell.  The loan will be the 1st loan taken out by the borrower from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Loan plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of the borrower's children.


About the Other Borrowers in the Group:


1.  N. Thị Lan (48) is a 35 year-old female who is requesting a 3000000 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising livestock.


2.  M. Thị Hồng (47) is a 21 year-old female who is requesting a 3000000 VND loan to support her business in the services sector operating a service-based business.


3.  C. Thị H. Giang (52) is a 22 year-old female who is requesting a 3000000 VND loan to support her business in the food sector running a food stall.


4.  T. Thị Hồng (53) is a 36 year-old female who is requesting a 3000000 VND loan to support her business in the food sector running a food stall.


5.  H. Thị Bình  (54) is a 32 year-old female who is requesting a 3000000 VND loan to support her business in the services sector operating a service-based business.


About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

The mission of Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainable financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province.


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


Loan N. Thị (51) là 35 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Thanh Hoa.  Loan là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 6 các thành viên.  Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ..  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 9 Nam Ngan (08.1.9 Nam Ngan).


Trong khi không phải chỉ có các pH. thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ buôn bán các sản phẩm từ gạo trong cộng đồng địa pH..  Loan thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 5 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, Loan kiếm được khoảng 1500000 VND.  Vào 2009, Loan đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  Loan đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.    Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 3,000,000 VND.


Khoản vay sẽ là 1st khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.


Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:


1.  N. Thị Lan (48) là 35 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 3000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


2.  M. Thị Hồng (47) là 21 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 3000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực dịch vụ.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh trên cơ sở dịch vụ.


3.  C. Thị H. Giang (52) là 22 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 3000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là buôn bán quầy thực phẩm.


4.  T. Thị Hồng (53) là 36 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 3000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là buôn bán quầy thực phẩm.


5.  H. Thị Bình  (54) là 32 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 3000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực dịch vụ.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh trên cơ sở dịch vụ.


Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ vì Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa.


*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  ."

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Silvia

texts.es: La señora Silvia S. J. lleva 18 años casada con su esposo llamado J Cleofas el cual es el que aporta el ingresos al hogar el trabaja de soldador y la señora es ama de casa, ellos son un matrimonio que a sabido salir adelante con sus esfuerzos, ellos adquirieron una vivienda pero esta deteriorada y le falta hacerle algunas mejoras como lo son el techo, baño y piso, quieren mejorar para poder tener un patrimonio para sus hijos y sobre todo en buenas condiciones para que no pierda valor la vivienda.
texts.en:
Silvia S. J. has been married to her husband J Cleofas for 18 years. He has contributed income to the home from his job as a soldier, while Silvia has worked as a housewife. They have a marriage that has been able to move forward through their efforts. They have purchased a house but it is in bad shape; the roof, bathroom and floors need improving. They want to improve the house to create an asset for their children, which above all should be in good condition so that it does not lose its value.

Translated from Spanish by Suzanne Grasso, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Roof, bathroom and floor repairs

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy pagne cloth and footwear to sell

loans.name: Irela  Rosa

texts.es: La Señora Irela L.  es una persona que labora a la Alcaldía de Managua como Secretaria. Tiene un hijo  no está en edad escolar. Este cliente ha obtenido dos créditos con CEPRODEL los cuales le han servido para resolver pagos de tarjetas de créditos que actualmente estaba en mora. Es un excelente  cliente con pagos puntuales. Es una persona trabajadora y puntual en sus pagos.
texts.en:
Irela L. works as a secretary for the mayor’s office in Managua. She has a child who is too young for school. She has had two loans with Ceprodel, which she used to pay her credit cards. They were delinquent. She is an excellent client with punctual payments. She is hard-working and punctual with her payments.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Pay past due credit cards

loans.name: Patricia

texts.en: Patricia is a well-known business woman in Agbor, Delta state. She sells cooking oil at retail prices to her customers. She has been in this business for a long time. She hopes to be a major cooking oil distributor in the future. She sells for long hours to support her family by meeting their basic needs. She is 42 years old, married with six children. Her eldest child is 25 years old. Her husband is a teacher in a government primary school in Agbor, Delta State. She is requesting a loan of NGN 100,000, to purchase more cooking oil to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more cooking oil to sell

loans.name: Lukuman

texts.en:
Lukuman is 40 years old. He is married with 3 children. He is a focused and hardworking man and he is a member of LAPO.

He sells foodstuffs like yams and tomato seeds to earn a living. He has been in business for over 20 years. Lukuman's focus is to expand his business. He is also doing all he can to pull his family to a higher financial level.

One of Lukuman's greatest joys is the one-on-one interactions he is able to have with his customers.

Lukuman is requesting a loan of N100,000 to purchase more foodstuffs, like yams and tomato seeds, to sell.

He says thank you.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Rosa Hortencia

texts.es:
El banco comunal Porvenir está conformado por un grupo de mujeres que buscan la manera de adelante y brindarles  una vida mejor a sus familias, todas  viven en la ciudad de Cuenca, localidad que  se caracteriza por ser la tercera  más importante del país y por la hermosura de su paisaje andino.

Rosa tiene una gran amistad con todas sus compañeras de la banco comunal, tiene 20 ciclos trabajando con los prestamos que la fundación le ha entregado y éstos le han permitido elaborar sus manualidades y artesanias, fue una amiga quien le incentivo para que integre el banco y reciba los beneficios que la institución ofrece.

 Ella elabora bordados, velas y  adornos decorativos, aprendió esta labor y ya lleva  8 años  cuenta con un local en el centro de la ciudad de Cuenca, labora de 9 a.m. hasta las 6 p.m. de lunes a sábado.

Rosa vive en el en la urbe de la ciudad de Cuenca, tiene 34 años de edad y se encuentra casada, tiene dos hijos de 8 y 6 años, su esposo también es artesano y tiene un pequeño taller de hierro forjado, no tienen casa propia por lo que viven en casa de su mamá pero en forma independiente,.

Con el nuevo préstamo que realiza en la fundación va  a invertir en su negocio en la compra de materiales para realizar sus manualidades como pintura, cerámica, hilos  etc..

Su meta es seguir trabajando y ahorrar para seguir creciendo con su  negocio.
texts.en:
The community bank Porvenir is made up of a group of women who are looking to get ahead and provide a better life for their families. They all live in the city of Cuenca, a town portrayed as being the third most important in the country for the beauty of its Andean landscape.

Rosa has a great friendship with all of her partners in the community bank. She has worked through 20 loan cycles that the foundation has given her and these loans have allowed her to make her handicrafts. It was one of her friends who motivated her to join the bank and receive the benefits that the institution offers. She makes embroidered goods, candles, and decorative ornaments. She learned how to do this work and has been doing it for 8 years in downtown Cuenca. She works from 9 a.m. until 6 p.m., Monday to Saturday.

Rosa lives in the urban part of the city of Cuenca. She is 34 years old, married, and has two children who are 8 and 6 years old. Her husband is also an artisan and he has a small iron-forging shop. They don’t have their own home so they live independently in her mother’s house.With the new loan from the foundation, she is going to invest in the purchase of materials to do her work such as paint, ceramics, thread, etc. Her goal is to continue working and save in order to continue growing her business.

Translated from Spanish by Kelley Maynard, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of paint, ceramics, thread, etc.

loans.name: Fatou

texts.fr: Madame Fatou N. est une yoffoise de38 ans qui habite a la cite Mame Rane, une des cites environnantes de Yoff. Elle est membre de l’U-IMCEC depuis janvier 2009et n’a bénéficié d’un prêt antérieur. Elle est mariée et mère de 2 enfants dont l’âge varie entre 5 et 14 ans. Son activité préférée demeure la couture qu’elle exerce avec beaucoup de passion. Plus précisément  elle fait la couture générale, vend des habits et des tissus qu’elle confectionne. Elle capitalise une expérience de 6 ans. Elle sollicite un crédit de 500 000 frs pour acquérir une machine cornière ceci dans le but de mieux répondre a la demande de sa clientèle. Une autre partie du financement sera orientée à l’achat de tissus a confectionner. Son souhait est d’augmenter ses gains et améliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille.
texts.en:
Mrs. Fatou N. is a 38-year-old woman from Yoff, who lives in the Mame Rane development, one of several in the Yoff area. She is a member of the U-IMCEC credit union since January 2009, and has not been granted any prior loan. She is married and mother of two children, age 5 and 14. Her favourite activity remains sewing, which she practices with passion. Specifically, she does all-around sewing, selling clothes and fabrics that she assembles. She has an accumulated six years of experience. She is requesting a loan of 500,000 francs to purchase a special embroidery machine, to better respond to customers’ demands. Another portion of the loan will be devoted to buying pieces of fabric. Her hope is to increase her earnings and improve her family’s living conditions.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Investment

loans.name: Rutheda

texts.en:
Mrs Rutheda E. is from Tambulig, Zamboanga del Sur. She is 59 years old, married, and has 5 children. She has a business called a LAPAKANAY. This is made of abaka and they are the suppliers for handicraft businesses. She earns approximately 4000PHP a month.

Rutheda joined PMPC to gain access for financial support and to engage in other business activities. She has a loan of 3000PHP, taken from PMPC and it is the 1st cycle upon availing. This loan has been used as additional capital for her LAPAKANAY project.

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital for her lapakanay business.

loans.name: Folake

texts.en:
Folake sells plastics, including baskets and kegs. She has been in this trade for many years. She also has a shop where she sells and rents video compact discs. 

She is requesting a loan of NGN 120,000 to buy plastics in bulk from the factory to sell. She said this will reduce her costs, including the cost of transporting the goods to market, and increase her profit. She will be able to serve her clients better and also assist her husband, who is a clergyman, to keep and care for their home.

Folake is 40 years old and married, and she has four children. She and her family lives in Lagos State. She expresses her gratitude to all lenders.

loans.use: To buy plastics in bulk to sell

loans.name: Juana Licelda

texts.es:
La Sra. Juana Licelda R.  tiene una Pulpería en su casa de habitación que está ubicada en el municipio del viejo.
Ella va a utilizar el crédito para pagar todos los impuestos del año en curso, además va a comprar un poco de mercadería como arroz, frijoles, azúcar, aceite, etc.

La Sra. Licelda es madre soltera de un hijo pero con mucho esfuerzo ha podido educarlo y salir adelante con el. Además dice que gracias a la ayuda que  ha tenido por parte de CEPRODEL  ha podido salir adelante para educarlo y surtir su pulpería para mantener su negocio activo.
texts.en:
Sra. Juana Licelda R. has a store in her home, which is located in the town of El Viejo. She will use this loan to pay her annual taxes. In addition she will buy some merchandise such as rice, beans, sugar, oil, and other items.

Sra. Licelda is a single mother with a son. With great effort, she has been able to move forward and provide him with an education. She also thanks CEPRODEL for the support that allowed her to pay for her son’s education and restock her store so that she can maintain an active business.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase merchandise for her store & pay her annual taxes

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! This is 70-year-old Maria Landi P. from Morogoro. She is widowed with five children between the ages of 12 and 25.

Maria has been running a milk business since 2008. Selling milk is a common business for Tanzanian women, especially Masai women. (the Masai are a tribe found in the northern part of Tanzania). Masai people do not cultivate farms but they own large numbers of cows, goats and sheep. One person can have more than one hundred cows and more than two hundred goats.

They sell their milk in order to get money so that they can buy other food such as maize and beans and to meet other expenses. The milk business is a very successful business because milk is in high demand by many people. Milk contains all the necessary ingredients and vitamins needed for health.

Maria works at her business for 5 to 8 hours per day, 3 days per week, and is assisted by her children. She is requesting a loan of 300,000 Tsh in order to purchase cups, bowls and baskets for her business. In the future, she plans to provide more litres of milk for her customers. Maria thanks you for your support!


About SELFINA: 
SELFINA has taken a leading role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility.

Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

One of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase cups, bowls, baskets and other vessels  for carrying milk as well as animal feeder .

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebecca N. is from the village of Binahalan, Gingoog City. She is 55 years old, married, and has six adult-aged children. To make a living, Rebecca owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. The main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting banana and other crops, like copra and cassava, for sale. Rebecca has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2010, Rebecca joined Kiva partner, HSPFI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income.

About HSPFI
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Marenco Group

texts.es:
El grupo Marenco está integrado por tres mujeres trabajadoras una de ellas es Josefa Leonarda E.  de 54 años quien se dedica a  realizar costura  como camisetas, vestidos etc. desde 1980. Ella con el préstamo compra materiales como telas, hilos, botones etc. para aumentar su negocio.

Sus compañeras de grupo son Patricia Lucia A. Espiniza quien a la edad de catorce años empezó a realizar trabajos de costuras y  Celania de la Asunción C. Marenco trabaja en Textil y vestuario desde la edad de 18 años cuando aprendió abordar con unas vecinas y el cual ha ido perfeccionando con nuevas técnicas y tendencias.  El trabajo de ella lo promueve a través de Ferias Nacionales, Fiestas Patronales y cruceros y muy pronto si Dios se lo permite llegara las ferias internacionales.
texts.en:
The Marenco group is made up of three hard-working women. One of them is Josefa Leonarda E., 54, who is a seamstress; she has made shirts, dresses, etc. since 1980. She will use the loan to buy materials like fabric, thread, buttons, etc. to increase her business. Her fellow group members are: Lucia A. Espiniza who has been a seamstress since the age of 14 and Asunción C. Marenco who has worked in textiles and dressmaking since she was 18 years old and learned to embroider from some neighbors; since then she has been perfecting her work with new techniques and trends. She promotes her work at national markets, patron saint feast days, cruises and very soon, God permitting, international markets.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy materials like fabric, thread, etc.

loans.name: Federico

texts.es: Federico, de 23 años, es un joven muy trabajador y alegre, vive en la casa de su madre junto a sus hermanos menores y lo que más desea es mejorar su calidad de vida. Trabajando todos los días arduamente en sus cultivos, Federico trata de cambiar la vida que actualmente lleva, junto a su madre siembran semestralmente habas, maíz, choclos y papa, los cuales venden en los mercados de Tarma y La Merced, ya que es ahí donde mejores ganancias obtienen., lleva 15 años realizando esta actividad y considera que le gusta cuidar sus siembras de plagas, sin embargo lo más difícil, es llevar sus cultivos hasta los mercados donde los vende, ya que los sacos que lleva son muy pesados. Su mayor anhelo es mejorar la calidad de sus productos y así obtener mejores ingresos. Este es su segundo crédito con MFP, siente que este crédito le será muy beneficioso en su crecimiento como agricultor. En su grupo comunal es un socio muy participativo y solidario. Con los dos mil nuevos soles que solicita, comprara más abono y fertilizantes y con eso mejorar la productividad de sus chacras.
texts.en:
Federico, of 23 years, is a happy and very industrious young man. He lives in his mother's house along with his smaller brothers. What he wants most is to improve his quality of life. He works arduously every day in his fields. Federico tries to change the life that he has at present. Along with his mother he sows beans, corn, maize and potatoes bi-annually, which he sells in the markets of Tarma and la Merced, since it is there that he obtains better profits. He has been doing this activity for 15 years and considers that he likes to protect his crops from plagues. Without doubt, the most difficult thing is to carry his crop to the markets where he sells them, since the bags that he carries are very heavy. His hope is to improve the quality of his products and thus to obtain a better income. This is his second loan with MFP. He feels that this loan will be very beneficial for him in his growth as a farmer. In his communal group he is a supportive and very active associate. With the two thousand new soles that he requests, he will buy more pesticides and fertilizer in order to improve the productivity of his small farm.

Translated from Spanish by Barbara (B) Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and pesticides to improve the productivity of his farm

loans.name: Them

texts.en:
Every day, Them L. wakes up before dawn and travels to where the fishermen work. She buys their fish in bulk and hurries back to sell the fish at the market for a profit. Her husband works selling ducks and chickens. The couple are always working and, together, they generate enough income to support their three small kids, who are enrolled in primary school.

Them L. will use half of the loan she has requested as capital for her husband’s business and the rest of the loan will be used to buy more fish to meet the needs of her customers.

loans.use: To buy more fish for her business plus provide capital for her husband's business

loans.name: Marites

texts.en:
Twenty-nine year old Marites A. is from the town of Sta. Josefa. She is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Marites owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. She also raises pigs and then resells them. Marites has been engaged in her business for over 6 years already.

Marites joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marites has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Marites is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers, seeds and other farm inputs. This loan will be the eighth loan taken out by Marites from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers, seeds and other farm inputs.

loans.name: Mercedes Victoria

texts.es: Mercedes Victoria tiene 32 años, su actividad es la venta de tortillas y servicio de triciclo. Ella lo inicia con el objetivo de estar más cerca de sus hijos y poder, por lo que tiene más de 3 años en este negocio tiene 3 hijos quienes se encuentran de 10, 8, 6 años de edad, pues siempre está buscando la forma de generar ingresos para la familia. Por lo que siempre ha sido una mujer muy luchadora y que disfruta de su actividad y de interactuar con sus clientes. Ella está solicitando este financiamiento para capital de trabajo para la compra de matera prima como maíz, cal, leña, comal y bolsas plásticas. Siempre sueña con agrandar su negocio.
texts.en:
Mercedes Victoria is 32 years old. Her business is selling tortillas and transportation using a three-wheeled vehicle. She started her business with the aim of being closer to her children. She has operated this business for more than 3 years, and she has three children, who are now 10, 8 and 6. She is always looking for ways to generate income for her family. She has always been a very hard-working woman, and she enjoys her work and the interactions with her customers. She is requesting this loan to use for working capital, buying raw materials such as corn, lime, firewood, a tortilla cooker and plastic bags. Her ongoing dream is to expand her business.

Translated from Spanish by Patricia Linderman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Betrice

texts.en: Betrice D. is currently in the business of selling various drugs at the medical clinic and is requesting a loan to stock more drugs to sell.  Betrice is 32 years old, married, and her husband is a director. She has three children who all go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build wards for admitting patients.

loans.use: Stock more drugs to sell

loans.name: Eugenia

texts.es: Eugenia, de 50 años de edad, está casada y tiene seis hijos en su haber. Juntos viven en la comunidad de Villa Quintiarina, ubicada en la selva tropical peruana, donde tienen su propia casa a base de adobe. El negocio al que de dedica es la venta de cacao tanto en su comunidad como en otras localidades. Se siente muy contenta con su trabajo y por todas las cosas que ha logrado hasta el momento, incluso sus ventas aumentaron tempestivamente con respecto a los años anteriores. Usualmente trabaja conjuntamente con su esposo y juntos hacen un buen equipo de trabajo, pero en tiempo de vacaciones recibe la ayuda de sus hijos, sin embargo en temporada de cosecha tiene a cargo de sus peones para que le faciliten en la extracción y traslado de su producto final hacia los centros de acopio, y de esa forma pueda venderlos. Su plan futuro es abrir una tienda, con la finalidad de que pueda diversificar su cartera de clientes y a la vez mejorar su calidad de vida. Este es su séptimo  crédito con MFP, por el cual asegura cumplir fielmente con sus respectivos pagos, además está satisfecha con su banco comunal, ya que le trae muchos beneficios. Con el crédito que solicita lo piensa invertir en la educación de sus cuatro hijos y el resto será destinado para que acondicione su hogar.
texts.en:
Eugenia is 50 years old, married, and has six children. They live in the community of Villa Quintiarina, located in the Peruvian tropical jungle, in their own adobe home. Business-wise, she dedicates herself the selling of cacao, both in her own community as well as in other localities. She is very content with her work, and for everything that she has managed to achieve to date. In addition, her sales have increased when compared to previous years. She usually works alongside her husband and, together, they make a good team. During vacations, she gets help from her children. During harvest time, however, she has laborers that help her extract and transport her final product to the supply centers so it can be sold. Her plan for the future is to open a store, with the aim of diversifying her customer base to further improve her standard of living. This is her seventh credit with MFP, and she assures us she plans to faithfully comply with her payments. In addition, she is satisfied with her cooperative bank as it provides her with many benefits. She plans to use the loan to invest in the educations of four children, and the rest will be used to improve her home.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For the educational expenses of her children.

loans.name: Rosa Mercedes

texts.es: Rosa es de 34 años de edad, casada, tiene un hijo varón y una mujer, es comerciante se dedica a la venta de cortes y blusas típicas, en la actividad tiene 3 años de experiencia, solicita su primer crédito para capital de trabajo, las referencias personales indican que es una persona responsable y trabajadora, por tal motivo no tendrá inconvenientes para pagar el préstamo.
texts.en:
Rosa is 34 years old, married, and she has a son and a daughter. She sells clothing and traditional blouses, a business where she has earned 3 years' experience. She requests a first time loan to supplement her working capital. Her personal references illustrate that she is a responsible and hard working person, which is why she is not expected to have difficulties with this loan.

Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital.

loans.name: Martha Eliuth

texts.es:
la sra. Martha Eliuth S. C. se dedica a la fabricacion de reposteria en general, su negocio opera bajo el nombre de “REPOSTERIA MI PROSPERIDAD” que se encuentra ubicado en la calle principal de la colonia Kennedy. Martha tiene 2 meses de tener su negocio, anteriormente lo tenía dentro de las instalaciones de Coacel, pero se salió ya que quería hacer crecer su negocio con mas clientela.
Martha elabora pan, pasteles, galletas, boquitas, desayunos, almuerzos, refrescos naturales y golosinas.
el credito lo utilizara para la compra de una Batidora, moldes y materia prima para realizar el pan y la reposteria.
texts.en:
Martha Eliuth S. C. makes general desserts. Her business operates under the name “Reposteria Mi Prosperidad” (My Prosperity Desserts), and is located on the main street in the Kennedy neighborhood. Martha has had her business in this location for two months; it used to be located within the Coacel complex, but she moved it because she wanted to be able to grow her business and increase her customer base. Martha makes breads, cakes, cookies, snacks, breakfast, lunches, natural soft drinks, and sweets. She will use the money from this loan to buy a mixer, bread and dessert molds and supplies.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Tools of the trade

loans.name: Hoy

texts.en:
Hoy R., 41, lives in the Takeo province. She is married and has three children living at home. 

She is a garment factory worker, typically making US$3 each day. Her husband works collecting recycling items; he typically makes about US$15 in revenue each day. 

Hoy R. would like a loan of US$800 to purchase a motorbike to commute to work.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike to commute to work

loans.name: Maria

texts.es: María, de 41 años, vive en su casa propia en compañía de su hija, que es mayor de edad; juntas se esfuerzan cada día por salir adelante. Desde hace 10 años, instaló en su casa una tienda de comestibles donde ofrece variados productos de primera necesidad. Se despierta todos los días muy temprano y empieza a trabajar a las 6 de la mañana hasta las 11 de la noche. Le gusta mucho atender su negocio porque lo realiza en la tranquilidad de su casa, además cuenta con la ayuda de su hija. Su tienda es la más surtida de la zona por donde vive, lo que le genera regulares ganancias que le permiten mantener su hogar sin que le falte nada. Esta muy satisfecha, pues poco a poco ha logrado salir adelante, todavía recuerda, cuando empezó con solo algunos comestibles; hoy hasta vende gas por galones a sus vecinos. Como es una mujer emprendedora para el futuro tiene pensado  ampliar las instalaciones de su tienda, además de surtirla de mayor variedad de productos. Es el tercer  crédito que tiene con MFP y promete cumplir con sus cuotas puntualmente ya que no quiere defraudar a las personas que hicieron posible el dinero que le permitirá continuar trabajando en busca del progreso. María tiene planeado invertir el crédito solicitado en la compra de una vitrina y una congeladora que necesita para implementar mejor su negocio, así espera mejorar sus ganancias.
texts.en:
María, age 41, lives in her own house with her adult daughter.  They put forth great effort every day in order to get ahead.  Ten years ago they established a food store in their house.  They sell various basic needs products.

She gets up very early every day, and she starts work at six in the morning.  She works until eleven at night.  She likes tending to the business because she can do it from the tranquility of her house.  Also, she has her daughter’s help.  Her store is the best stocked store in the area where she lives.  It generates regular income, which allows her to support her household with everything they need.
